title-group.article-title: Baby on board: pregnancy as a source of conflict for the psychiatry registrar

contrib-group.aff: Psychiatry registrar, South Brisbane, QLD, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Dr Laura Hamilton, South Brisbane, 4101 QLD, Australia Email: hamiltonpsychiatry@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists 2013
permissions.copyright-holder: The Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: A literature review explores the author’s experience of conflict while working as a psychiatry registrar during her pregnancy.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Conflicts may arise during a registrar’s pregnancy, but can be mediated through effective supervision and peer support, and may benefit future clinical practice with the development of new insights and enhanced self-awareness.

body.p: I was 12 weeks pregnant when I began working as a registrar in consultation liaison psychiatry in a perinatal mental health service. Initially I had not considered that pregnancy would impact significantly on my work. Any concerns I did have related to systems issues such as applying for maternity leave. I knew this would cause a staffing shortage, and I felt guilty for burdening other trainees.

As my pregnancy progressed, I became increasingly anxious about my interactions with certain patients, especially women post still-birth. I worried that my obvious pregnancy would upset these women further, and found it difficult to hear their stories of grief and loss.

When patients asked about my pregnancy, I felt uncomfortable with a loss of privacy and anonymity. I wondered whether to answer these questions politely, or decline to answer at all. When reviewing pregnant patients, it seemed artificial and insincere to deny or ignore this obviously shared experience, but the difference between acceptable self-disclosure and boundary crossing was not always clear. I saw myself and my own life reflected in these women and their stories, which at times led to over-identification.

Supervision became an important forum for exploring my experiences, helping me to identify some of the dynamics affected by my pregnancy. During consultations I would hear of traumatic births, strained relationships and disrupted attachments. Though currently a doctor, I was about to become a patient. I was uncomfortable with this role-reversal, which prompted a heightened awareness of my own insecurities and deficiencies.

Despite the number of conflicts I experienced, there was a significant unexpected benefit to my pregnancy. Education is an important part of consultation liaison psychiatry, but I have always found it difficult to generate enthusiasm for discussion of psychodynamic issues amongst non-psychiatrists. However, my pregnancy seemed to spontaneously elicit such discussions. The natural curiosity of my colleagues created a unique opportunity for informal education, enabling these professionals to reflect on their own interactions with patients, resulting in improved understanding of the dynamics of the doctor–patient relationship.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: The primary hypothesis for this review was that pregnancy affects the trainee psychiatrist by creating a tension between:

list-item.p: Doctor and service, affecting employment and training;
Doctor and patient, affecting the dynamics of this relationship;
Doctor and herself, an internal conflict for the doctor.

sec.p: A secondary hypothesis was that supervision and peer support can help to resolve these tensions.

Four databases were searched (CINAHL, Health Source, Medline and PsychINFO), using the terms ‘pregnancy psychiatry training’, and this generated 104 articles. When extended to include ‘pregnancy therapist’ and ‘pregnancy psychiatrist’ there were almost 400 additional results. To source more information, the search was expanded to include the terms ‘resident’, ‘doctor’, ‘midwife’, and ‘obstetrician and gynaecologist’. This generated a further four articles.
Information has also been included from the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists (RANZCP) Regulations and 2010 Education Activities Report.

sec.title: Tension between doctor and service
sec.p: The literature supports the assumption that a registrar’s pregnancy may affect employment and training, creating conflicts with colleagues and hospital departments.1

Colleagues may experience anger, hostility and jealousy if asked to assume a pregnant doctor's duties.2 This may be expressed overtly, or passively in the guise of humour or jokes about sex and sexuality.3 Alternatively, colleagues may become overly nurturing and protective of a pregnant doctor,3,4 representing maternal transference3 or a reaction to the pregnant doctor’s own feelings of increasing physical vulnerability.5

Contributing factors to conflict with colleagues include intrapsychic issues such as rage or envy and the small-group dynamics within a peer group.6 The pregnant trainee may react by down-playing her excitement or pleasure of pregnancy and impending motherhood.7,8

The service-related tensions created by a trainee’s pregnancy are not unique to psychiatry and extend to other specialties.9-11 Common issues include difficulties meeting work and home commitments and relying on colleagues to provide cover.12

A number of authors acknowledge that a doctor's pregnancy causes difficulties for hospitals8,13,14 and that women of childbearing age may be considered a ‘hiring risk’.15 Doctors may intentionally postpone pregnancy because of perceived threats to their careers.16 Hospitals and training programmes should accommodate childbearing and motherhood,8,14 in order to avoid unnecessary strain on the pregnant trainee and the hospital system.1,9,17

This is an important issue for the RANZCP, as the majority of psychiatry trainees are female.18 The RANZCP does make accommodation for pregnancy and motherhood, including permitting registrars to take breaks in training and work part-time.19 Despite these allowances, women may be disadvantaged by currency requirements19 and may decide to delay childbearing or shorten maternity leave in order to avoid having to repeat various mandatory requirements. Fortunately, the college recently amended its currency requirements to exclude the need to repeat examinations.18

sec.title: Tension between doctor and patient
sec.p: There is evidence that pregnancy changes the dynamics of the doctor–patient relationship. The doctor's pregnancy may be either facilitative or disruptive to the therapy, depending on the degree of resistance and the doctor’s response.20

Patients may experience a variety of emotions, including anger towards or envy of the therapist.21,22 There may be emergence of unresolved parental conflict,23 with the therapist viewed as an idealised mother.24 A ‘sibling rivalry’ can develop between patient and the unborn baby, in competition for the therapist’s attention.25,26 Some patients may experience death wishes towards the foetus.27 Alternatively, patients may feel guilty, perceiving that they are receiving the attention of the therapist to which her baby is entitled.28 Some subgroups of patients are likely to have specific challenges, for instance anorexic patients with a fear of sexual maturity, or those with borderline personality disorder who struggle with attachment and abandonment.20 Grief reactions are common across many groups of patients.29

A therapist’s pregnancy can change the power-balance in the doctor–patient relationship. Patients who are more experienced parents may give the doctor advice about pregnancy and motherhood. This creates a role-reversal with the patient as the expert assuming a more authoritative role, and a subsequent loss of status for the doctor.23,27

Pregnancy is visible evidence of a therapist’s sexuality.23,28 In some cases, this prompts a patient to discuss normally taboo subjects such as sex,30 or even develop sexual feelings towards the therapist.21

A therapist’s pregnancy usually signals an inevitable termination, or at least suspension, of therapy.23 The patient may feel abandoned,21,23 angry that the therapist has put her own needs above those of the patient.21,31 Termination may be perceived as a violation of an initial contract with the therapist.20,31

A patient’s particular response will be influenced by a number of factors, including the person’s own underlying character structure32 and attachment style.29 Other variables include the phase of treatment, the therapist’s countertransference and the therapeutic technique being used.20,33

When doctor and patient are simultaneously pregnant, the patient may feel in competition with the therapist.30 Women seeking abortion counselling may feel particularly uncomfortable with a pregnant therapist.20

Anticipating the patient’s potential responses in advance may help the therapist to negotiate conflicts and modify treatment accordingly.32 Ideally, a therapist’s pregnancy could be integrated into therapy in a positive way.34 Changing dynamics may facilitate new insights and therapeutic gains26,30,33 or even assist patients to process conflicts around self-identity, sexuality and physical maturity.20

sec.title: Tension between doctor and herself
sec.p: When pregnant, the doctor experiences the patient role first hand, heightening awareness of her own vulnerabilities.27 Difficulties in combining the demands of professional practice and motherhood can result in further feelings of inadequacy.8,17,22 Pregnancy is ranked as one of the most stigmatising conditions for a trainee, along with alcohol abuse and panic attacks.35 Fears about negative impacts on training or employment may influence a doctor’s willingness to seek self-care, compromising her own health and that of her unborn baby.35

A woman undergoes a series of psychological changes over the course of pregnancy, influenced by her own pre-existing personality33 and the process of pregnancy itself.30 A woman may feel discomfort over a changing identity or body image.30 As pregnancy becomes more physically obvious, it is more likely to attract enquiry from patients, with the doctor experiencing an invasion of privacy.23 The pregnant therapist may become more egocentric and pre-occupied with herself and her unborn child.5,23,27 These internal conflicts influence countertransference reactions and potentially compromise the therapist’s objectivity and neutrality.33,36

The ability of a therapist to remain neutral may be challenged by some sub-groups of patients, for instance those women seeking abortion counselling.20 This situation is described by Millward,37 who relates her experiences working in a termination clinic during pregnancy. Millward describes her countertransference reactions, speaking of her own ‘unease’ at being pregnant, and the ‘confused, guilty look’ of her patients.37 Respondents to this article commented on similar experiences as pregnant physicians.38

Concerns about whether and when to disclose a pregnancy are common for many pregnant therapists.33 A therapist may feel conflicted, simultaneously wanting to conceal the pregnancy, but also to share the excitement.22 If the patient becomes aware of the pregnancy before it is disclosed, then conflict may be unfairly shifted to the patient, who worries if or how they should discuss it with the therapist.22 In contrast, timely self-disclosure by the therapist can be used to create an atmosphere of trust and rapport.27

An additional benefit of pregnancy is the potential for the therapist to gain new insights. The therapist may enhance her clinical practice by developing a greater appreciation of the challenges of parenting, or more understanding of developmental phases and struggles.39

sec.title: The role of supervision and peer support
sec.p: While a doctor’s pregnancy may create conflict with colleagues and peers, negative responses are not universal and peers can provide an important support network for the pregnant trainee.7,10 This is highlighted by Stewart and Robinson,8 who state, ‘Along with a supportive spouse and good childcare, the attitudes of colleagues and supervisors and the need for good role models were... critical to the success of combining a psychiatric career with motherhood.’

An effective supervisor will be aware of the potential for a trainee’s pregnancy to trigger conflicts and encourage early discussion of these issues.4 The supervisor should pre-empt the likelihood of altered dynamics within supervision itself.40 The pregnant therapist may feel vulnerable, anxious or guilty, but defend against these emotions in an attempt to minimise the impact of her pregnancy.40 The supervisor should be on the alert for such defences and assist the trainee to increase awareness of these internal conflicts.40 Effective supervision is important for support and encouragement of personal reflection.40

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The literature supports the hypothesis that pregnancy is a source of conflict for the psychiatry registrar, which is reflected in the author’s personal experiences of internal anxieties as well as external tensions in relationships with patients and colleagues. The evidence supports the role of supervision and peer support in mediating these conflicts. A registrar’s pregnancy may facilitate the development of new insights and a greater understanding of the dynamics of the doctor–patient relationship.

sec.title: Areas for future research
sec.p: It is likely that similar conflicts are experienced by other health-care workers during pregnancy. The paucity of literature on this subject may reflect a lack of knowledge or understanding of transference and countertransference reactions within the general medical workforce. It would be interesting to know if these professionals experience similar tensions when pregnant and how these are understood and managed.

This review found little information relating specifically to consultation liaison psychiatry. It may be that a therapist’s pregnancy affects these often more transient relationships differently from long-term therapeutic relationships.

Literature was lacking on the subject of simultaneous pregnancy of doctor and patient. Those articles that did refer to this were written from the therapist’s perspective, and so were influenced by the therapist’s own countertransference reactions. It would be informative to survey patients directly.

Further information would be valuable in assisting the RANZCP to direct future policies regarding training requirements. Considering that the median age for females to attain Fellowship is 37 years,18 it is likely that many women experience pregnancy during their psychiatry training and may benefit from more tailored supervision or support. While the college records the numbers of trainees who take a break in training, the reasons for these interruptions are not collated (Fletcher S, RANZCP, personal communication, 2011). Data is kept on cessation of training for ‘personal or family’ reasons,18 but this category is too broad to predict the number withdrawing specifically due to pregnancy or motherhood. Without more data, it is difficult to know whether current regulations and policies are effective in meeting the needs of women who may become pregnant during their psychiatry training.

fn.label: Disclosure
fn.p: The author reports no conflict of interest. The author alone is responsible for the content and writing of the paper.
